courseDescription: This course provides a basic introduction to the study of international politics.  It considers some of the more prominent theoretical perspectives in the discipline and examines the major political, economic, social and environmental issues presently facing the global community. The course prepares students for advanced study in international politics.
Technical and Digital Skills: Researching political, economic, social and environmental issues
Understanding and applying international politics theories
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing global political and economic trends
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and organizing a study plan

courseDescription: This course introduces students to the political processes and the institutions of American politics.  The course examines American political culture, gender and minority rights, citizen participation, national institutions, public policy, and foreign and defense policy.

courseTitle: Introduction to Comparative Government and Politics
courseDescription: This course introduces basic concepts and methods for the study of comparative politics. It also surveys and compares the political/socioeconomic development, political cultures/ideologies, political institutions, decision-making processes, and public policies of various countries in the world.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Articulation of political ideologies and cultures
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Interpretation of political institutions and their functions

courseDescription: Open only to students in the Honors College.  A special honors section of POLSÂ 101S.
An introduction to various approaches to policy making followed by a detailed study of several of the most important domestic contemporary issues (housing, transportation, education, welfare, etc.).

Introduces the student to the United States legal system through an examination of its institutions, practitioners, and processes. Assignments explore (1) the anatomy of a law suit, (2) legal education in the United States, (3) basic methods of legal reasoning, writing, and argumentation, and (4) the function of judicial precedent within United States courts. This is a writing intensive course.
In-depth analysis of the American court system with an emphasis on the political behavior of the system's participants and the procedural dimensions of the court system.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of political behavior of court system participants
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Understanding and applying procedural dimensions of court systems
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Applying legal analysis to real-world scenarios

courseDescription: Development of criminal procedure under the United States Constitution, with particular emphasis on the Fourth, Fifth, Sixth, Eighth, and Fourteenth Amendments as interpreted by the U.S. Supreme Court.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of legal cases and precedents

courseDescription: Covers the design and implementation of quantitative and qualitative methods of inquiry in social sciences.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem-solving in research design and implementation

courseDescription: This course examines the public policy problems of various racial groups in America.  It analyzes the extent to which the American political system protects and promotes the concerns of African Americans, Hispanics, Native Americans and Asians.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of public policy issues
Understanding and articulating concerns of different racial groups
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluation of racial concerns in public policy

courseDescription: The study of political theory delves into the central concepts that shape humanityâs capacity to think about and practice politics, including justice, liberty, equality, human nature, rights, power, democracy, and the various potential goals of political community. Students will study influential political thinkers such as Plato, Aristotle, Cicero, Augustine of Hippo, Thomas Aquinas, Machiavelli, Hobbes, Locke, Mill, Marx and Rawls.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Comparison and contrast of differing political theories

courseDescription: This course is a survey of Virginia state and local government institutions, functions, processes, and behavior of political actors.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication in a political context
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Understanding and analyzing government institutions and processes

courseDescription: The course considers the origins, evolution, purposes, and relevancy of American political thought.  It includes studies in democracy versus elitism; civil disobedience versus revolution; liberalism versus conservatism.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Debate and discussion of political ideologies
Presenting nuanced understandings of political theories
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Understanding and interpretation of political evolution
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership through understanding of political ideologies

courseDescription: An examination of the United Nations and key issues facing the international community.  Includes a three-day visit to United Nations headquarters in New York.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Formulating potential solutions to international problems
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning for the visit to the UN headquarters

courseDescription: Analyzes and compares the major political functions and the social, economic, and cultural bases of European states.  Also examines the contemporary movement for European economic, military, and political unity.
Technical and Digital Skills: Analysis of political, social, economic, and cultural data
Understanding and interpreting policies and international agreements
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussion and debate on political topics
Interpretation and explanation of complex political concepts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Understanding and analyzing contemporary movements and trends
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Knowledge of organizational structures in European politics

courseDescription: This course is intended to familiarize students with the struggles, advances, and setbacks of African peoples for state-building and socioeconomic development during the colonial and post-independence eras.
A survey of the lobby movement in America, its history and present status, with particular attention to current lobbies and interest groups and their impact on the national government.

Since it was established in 1945 the UN has inspired humanity, undertaken many of the worldâs most difficult jobs, and provided great achievements and disappointments. This course examines the functioning of the UN, what it does best and worst, and the prospects for UN reform.

What are the roles and capabilities of the international organizations? This course examines the principles behind the worldâs 300 IOs, including specialized, technical, and regional organizations, as well as alliances and non-governmental organizations. When do they replace states and other actors? When are they essential, when are they helpful adjuncts, and when are they irrelevant? This is a writing intensive course.
Technical and Digital Skills: Research and evaluation of specialized and technical organizations
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Understanding the roles and capabilities of international organizations
Communication of principles and roles of various IOs
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of the relevance of international organizations
Understanding when IOs replace states and other actors
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding the organizational structure and roles of international organizations
Assessing the effectiveness of alliances and non-governmental organizations

courseDescription: Introduces students to the primary mechanisms of the global political economy in allocating goods, income, wealth and the means to produce them, with emphasis on the international division of labor.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of global political economy mechanisms
Knowledge of international division of labor
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaborative discussions on global economic issues
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Interpretation of wealth and income distribution patterns
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Strategic planning in international economic context

courseDescription: Comparative study of the various theories that attempt to explain the patterns of interactions among the different members of the global community.  Draws on historical and modern cases to explain traditional and alternative theories.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of international relations theories

courseDescription: This course is designed for intermediate students who are interested in the theoretical and systematic study of world politics.  The course first introduces students to several major theoretical approaches to the study of world politics, and then applies these approaches to a number of major issues--ranging from conflict and cooperation, arms control, the protection of human rights, international trade, economic development, and environmental preservation.  This is a writing intensive course.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying theoretical approaches to practical scenarios
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Evaluation of political and economic development strategies

courseDescription: This course presents those factors that go into the making and analyzing of American foreign policy, explores their application in decision making, and seeks to test their utilization against contemporary problems.  This is a writing intensive course.

Examination of issues facing America as it debates the use of international force, including the range of national security choices, defense reform, and the tensions between American resort to warfare and global trends transforming the ability to use violence effectively.  This is a writing intensive course.

Starting with the Soviet communist system, explores Russia's efforts to establish democracy and the rule of law, to fashion a productive, beneficial market economy, to establish viable relationships with the other former republics of the USSR and to craft advantageous foreign and military policies toward the West, Asia, and the developing countries.
This course is a survey of state and local government institutions, functions, processes, and behavior of political actors.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of state and local government institutions

courseDescription: Analyzes European politics from World War II to the present.  Emphasizes the foreign policies of major European states, including policies towards EU and  NATO. This is a writing intensive course.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of policies and events
Comparative analysis of different foreign policies
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and structuring complex written arguments

courseDescription: An examination of the development of the news media and the role of political communication and information in American politics.  Analysis of the newsmaking process; media coverage of political campaigns, the President and Congress; the impact of the news media on the American public; and the interaction between public officials and journalists.
Technical and Digital Skills: Evaluation of the impact of news media on the public
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Engaging with journalists and public officials
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of the interaction between public officials and journalists

courseDescription: A survey of electoral politics and behavior, including the structure of the electoral system, contemporary political campaigning, political partisanship, voting behavior, and role of interest groups in the electoral process.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Understanding the role of interest groups
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of electoral politics and behavior

courseDescription: This course examines the evolution of environmentalism in the United States, including the policy-making process, science and the role played by the public and political institutions.

This is a comparative study of the main political, economic and social developments in the major countries of South Asia.  Themes will include democratization, problems of economic development, the role of caste and religion, the causes of intrastate conflict and interstate conflict and the influence of global forces on the region.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Understanding and respecting diverse religious and societal norms
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of political, economic and social developments
Identification and understanding of causes of intrastate and interstate conflicts
Understanding and analysis of global forces' influences
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Analysis and understanding of leadership roles in conflict and development
Understanding societal organization through caste and religion

courseDescription: Examines the evolution of Latin American politics, including early colonial and caudillo rule, populism and radicalism, the emergence of military regimes, and the reestablishment of constitutional democracies.  Also considers contemporary economic, social, cultural, and environmental issues which condition state-society relations in the region.

This course examines political cultures/traditions, governmental institutions, decision-making processes, public policies, political organizations, and significant socio-political issues of such East Asian countries as China, Japan and Korea.  In addition, it explores the collective impact of these countries on world politics and global economy.  This is a writing intensive course.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussing world politics and global economy
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluating the impact of East Asian countries on world politics and global economy

courseDescription: This course examines the fundamental changes and continuities that the evolution of technology has brought to armed conflict.  It explores the historical development of technology and warfare, emphasizing the role of cultural, social and political choice shaping the development of new military technologies and affecting how they are used.  What is the future of Western assumptions about technologically dominated warfare?
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge on evolution of technology in warfare
Understanding of technology's impact on warfare
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussion of socio-political implications of technology in warfare
Debating on future of technologically dominated warfare
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing historical developments in technology and warfare
Critical evaluation of technological impacts on military strategies
Forecasting future trends in technologically dominated warfare

courseDescription: Student participation for credit based on the academic relevance of the work experience, criteria, and evaluative procedures as formally determined by the department and Career Development Services prior to the semester in which the work experience is to take place.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of academic relevance of work experience
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with department and Career Development Services

courseDescription: Individualized practical experience in public bureaucracies, political groups, administrative agencies or law firms.  Group seminars are held periodically under the supervision of faculty.  Credits are commensurate with the level of the student's involvement.
Technical and Digital Skills: Basic legal knowledge for working in law firms

courseDescription: A study of selected topics designed for nonmajors, or for elective credit within a major.  These courses and any additional prerequisites will appear in the course schedule, and will be more fully described in information distributed to all academic advisors.

A study of selected topics designed for nonmajors, or for elective credit within a major.  These courses and any additional prerequisites will appear in the course schedule, and will be more fully described in information distributed to all academic advisors.

This is a detailed study of the institutional and behavioral factors at work in legislative decision making, especially at the national level.  Emphases are on the interrelationships among Congress, the Presidency, and the bureaucracy and on learning how to do research on specific legislation.

This course analyzes the causes, severity, potential consequences, and proposed solutions regarding global ecological issues with special attention to the scientific debate and the political and policy process.  It examines environmental policies of national governments, regional/international organizations, and global conferences.
Technical and Digital Skills: Analysis of regional and international policies
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing potential solutions to ecological problems

courseDescription: The course explores the development of conflicting judicial and legal theories arising from Supreme Court enforcement of the First Amendmentâs protection of speech and religious freedoms. Supreme Court opinions, along with the underlying theories that inform its decisions and rationales, are the focus of the assignments and class discussion.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of Supreme Court rulings and legal theories
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of Supreme Court decisions

courseDescription: The course covers the development of presidential power and activity, the contemporary operations of the Presidency, and the problems which may confront the institution in the future.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding leadership dynamics within the Presidency

courseDescription: An examination of the vexatious line between the rights of individuals and those of the state in the American democracy, focusing on such major issues as freedom of expression and worship; freedom of the press; separation of church and state; privacy; and racial and gender discrimination.
Technical and Digital Skills: Digital literacy for accessing legal databases
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Assessment of racial and gender discrimination cases

courseTitle: American Constitutional Law: Powers of Government
courseDescription: An examination of separation of powers, federalism and the democratic process as reflected by Supreme Court decisions.  Also, the Supreme Court as a political institution.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of Supreme Court decisions

courseDescription: This course examines the political development of Black people in the United States by focusing on the relationship and processes of the American political system.  The political dynamics of Black political thought, the Civil Rights Movement, and Black protest politics are also analyzed.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication on racial and political issues
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of political systems and movements
Analysis of historical and contemporary political dynamics
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding and application of political strategies
Leadership in political activism and protest

courseTitle: Politics of the Civil Rights Movement
courseDescription: Examines the political activities which resulted in the passage of the nation's second Civil Rights policy, the 1960 and 1964 Civil Rights Acts, the 1965 Voting Rights Act and the 1968 Fair Housing Act. The course will analyze the underpinnings, leadership, and political strategies of the Civil Rights Movement.
Technical and Digital Skills: Research on historical and political events
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Analyzing the organizational structure of social movements

courseDescription: The question of power, often ignored by education policy analysts and researchers, is a principal focus of this seminar.  Issues ranging from the role of education in political socialization and the politics of affirmative action and equal opportunity are examined.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of political and educational concepts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Understanding and assessing affirmative action and equal opportunity issues

courseDescription: Examines women's place in political theory and the practice of politics in the United States. A major focus is to trace the development of women's political rights, the impact of public policy on the lives of American women and to see how women influence and participate in the political process.
Technical and Digital Skills: Researching historical and contemporary political events
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Tracing the development of women's political rights

courseDescription: A survey of and practicum in the basic techniques of quantitative research, including the logic of empirical research, the identification of data sources, and the use of appropriate statistical techniques.

An examination of the history of legal thought and developments of natural law, as well as an in-depth analysis of legal positivism and realism.  Particular attention is paid to American legal philosophy.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding the history of legal thought
Analysis of legal positivism and realism
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluating different schools of legal thought
Understanding the implications of legal positivism and realism

courseDescription: Course provides a basis for understanding the role and importance of international organizations in contemporary international relations.  Focuses on development and history of global organizations, with particular emphasis on the United Nations, and regional and functional organizations.
Technical and Digital Skills: Historical and contemporary global organization analysis
Understanding of the United Nations and other functional organizations
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presentation of global organizational theories and concepts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of global organization development
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding and analysis of organizational structures

courseDescription: This writing intensive course explores cybersecurity policy and strategy and introduces students to the essentials of strategy development and policy making in cybersecurity. Topics considered include planning principles in cyber strategy; risk management and cybersecurity policy; the connections between cybersecurity policies, businesses, and governmental institutions; the knowledge, skills, and abilities needed to develop and implement cybersecurity policy; the social, political and ethical implications that arise in cybersecurity policies and strategies; strategies to assess cybersecurity policy; and the ties between national security and cybersecurity policy.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communicating cybersecurity policies to businesses and governmental institutions
Understanding and addressing the social, political and ethical implications of cybersecurity policies
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the connections between cybersecurity policies and businesses or governmental institutions
Evaluating the effectiveness of cybersecurity policies
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Integrating cybersecurity policy into risk management
Balancing national security concerns with cybersecurity policy

courseDescription: This course explores the national security dimensions of cybersecurity and examines cyber war in international relations. Exploration of cyber war begins with an examination of cybersecurity as a component of national security and investigates the topics of U.S National Cybersecurity and other national approaches to cyber war.  The topics of cyber deterrence, cyber as a military domain, the roles of international organizations in cyber war, cyber terrorism, the role of social media, and information warfare will be discussed.  The international dimension of cybersecurity is also discussed.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of U.S National Cybersecurity and other national approaches to cyber war
Understanding of cyber as a military domain
Knowledge of the roles of international organizations in cyber war
Knowledge of the international dimension of cybersecurity
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to discuss complex cyber war topics
Understanding and communicating the role of social media in cyber war
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of national security dimensions of cybersecurity
Evaluation of different national approaches to cyber war
Understanding and analysis of the international dimension of cybersecurity
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding of the organizational role in cyber war
Understanding of the leadership role of international organizations in cyber war

courseTitle: Political Participation in the United States
courseDescription: An examination of current theories and research on political behavior, conventional and unconventional modes of political participation, and the impact of participation on the political system.

A study of origins of the Chinese revolution; development and functions of the Chinese Communist Party;  government institutions; the defense establishment; evolution of foreign policy; and post-Mao political and economic reforms.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Understanding of Chinese political and economic contexts
Ability to communicate about foreign policy
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of historical events and their impacts
Critical evaluation of political and economic reforms
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding of governmental and institutional structures
Insight into party leadership and defense establishment

courseDescription: A study of Japan's historical political development and social patterns; government institutions; problems of the constitution; and foreign and defense policy.
A study of contemporary issues (political, economic, and strategic) in the East Asia area; the interactions of China, Japan, the United States, and the former Soviet republics in East Asia.
Technical and Digital Skills: Research on global political, economic, and strategic issues
Understanding of international relations in East Asia
Knowledge on the interactions of China, Japan, the United States, and the former Soviet republics in East Asia
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to articulate complex international relations concepts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing political, economic, and strategic issues
Understanding and predicting interactions between different nations
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Ability to organize and synthesize complex information
Strategic planning in a global context

courseDescription: Students will study law as seen through the lens of fiction.  Assignments draw heavily from classic and contemporary novels, short stories, plays, films, and perhaps television.  As these artistic representations of law in action are explored, short theoretical readings help focus on questions of philosophy, politics, and justice.  The course also explores the relationship between fiction and reality through appellate opinions and contemporary literature on the American legal system.  The goal is to come to a better understanding of the potential blessings, dangers, and limitations of law.
Technical and Digital Skills: Exploring contemporary literature on American legal system
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Articulating philosophical, political and justice-related questions
Engaging in intellectual discourse on fiction and reality
Presenting interpretations of law in artistic media
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of law in fiction
Analyzing the relationship between fiction and reality
Assessing the blessings, dangers, and limitations of law

courseDescription: This course aims to expose students to an examination of the workings of international politics from the viewpoint of Africans and African states. International relations have tended to look at the world from the viewpoint of its most powerful states. Yet, most the world's states - notably in Africa - are weak but have great potential global impact.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussion and debate on international politics
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing potential impacts of weak states on global politics
Comparative analysis of different political viewpoints
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading discussions on complex international topics

courseDescription: A study of the Fascist, Nazi, Stalin and Mao regimes and the forces that brought them to power and sustained them, including a study of the impact of their policies on their people and neighboring states.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Debate and discussion of historical events
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Understanding and analyzing the societal impact of policies

courseDescription: Explores the essential characteristics of globalization and its implications for social relations and existing institutions.
Technical and Digital Skills: Analysis of societal and institutional changes
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Interpreting and explaining complex global phenomena
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing trends and patterns in global contexts
Identifying the implications of globalization on social relations and institutions
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing thoughts and ideas on complex global issues
Adapting to global changes and dynamics

courseDescription: An examination of the science of climate change and how United States political actors have responded to this global environmental challenge.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Debate and discussion on political issues
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading discussions on climate change politics

courseTitle: Weapons of Mass Destruction in Global Security
courseDescription: Since the end of the Cold War, weapons of mass destruction have emerged as one of the most dangerous and contentious issues in international affairs. The course examines how these weapons are made, how they proliferate, and how they are controlled.
Technical and Digital Skills: Analyzing digital data on weapons proliferation

courseDescription: This course focuses on one specific European country such as France, Germany, the United Kingdom, etc.  Examination of trends and events which most influenced  the evolution of domestic politics and foreign relations from World War II to the present.
Technical and Digital Skills: Researching historical and contemporary political trends
Usage of digital platforms for accessing geopolitical data
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Debate and discussion of political trends
Interpreting and conveying complex political concepts

courseTitle: Ethnic Conflict in the New Global Order
courseDescription: Ethnically based conflict is presently a pervasive worldwide phenomenon.  This course examines internal and external factors causing ethnic conflicts and mechanisms for resolving or mitigating such conflicts.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of conflict resolution mechanisms
Understanding of internal and external factors in conflict

courseDescription: An analysis of the political processes throughout the region and in selected nations of the Middle East.  Topics to be discussed include inter-Arab relations, the Arab-Israeli conflict, the Iran-Iraq rivalry and foreign power involvement in the Middle East.
Technical and Digital Skills: Data analysis on foreign power involvement

courseDescription: This course focuses on race, ethnicity, and the role and influence of African Americans in international affairs and American foreign policy making.  It investigates the activities of African Americans in the international arena.  The emphasis is on how African Americans have participated and the results of that participation from the era of slavery to Barack Obama.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the role of African Americans in international affairs
Assessing the influence of African Americans on American foreign policy
Evaluating the results of African American participation in international affairs
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading discussions on race and ethnicity

courseDescription: Interdisciplinary research and preparation of a senior thesis in international studies This is a writing intensive course.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of international studies research

courseDescription: The advanced study of selected topics in American politics designed to permit small groups of qualified students to work on subjects of mutual interest which, due to their specialized nature, may not be offered regularly.
An examination and discussion of critical world issues based upon the Foreign Policy Association's Great Decision Series.
The advanced study of selected topics in political science which, due to their specialized nature, may not be offered regularly.
The advanced study of selected topics which, due to their specialized nature, may not be offered regularly.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presenting specialized topics in a comprehensible manner
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of specialized political topics
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading discussions on specialized political topics

courseDescription: Independent research in political science under the supervision of a faculty member.
Independent research in political science under the supervision of a faculty member.
Technical and Digital Skills: Use of political science software tools

courseDescription: This course analyzes the causes, severity, potential consequences, and proposed solutions regarding global ecological issues with special attention to the scientific debate and the political and policy process. It examines environmental policies of national governments, regional/international organizations, and global conferences.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of policy processes at national and international levels

Supreme Court opinions, along with the underlying theories that inform its decisions and rationales, are the focus of the assignments and class discussion.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Understanding and application of legal rationales
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Analysis and organization of legal information

courseDescription: This course examines the political development of Black people in the United States by focusing on the relationship and processes of the American political system.  The political dynamics of Black political thought, the Civil Rights Movement, and Black protest politics are also analyzed.

courseTitle: Politics of the Civil Rights Movement
courseDescription: Examines the political activities which resulted in the passage of the nation's second Civil Rights policy, the 1960 and 1964 Civil Rights Acts, the 1965 Voting Rights Act and the 1968 Fair Housing Act. The course analyzes the underpinnings, leadership, and political strategies of the Civil Rights Movement.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding of leadership dynamics within social movements

courseDescription: The question of power, often ignored by education policy analysts and researchers, is a principal focus of this seminar.  Issues ranging from the role of education in political socialization and the politics of affirmative action and equal opportunity are examined.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Understanding and interpreting political and social contexts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of power dynamics in education
Critical scrutiny of affirmative action and equal opportunity policies

courseDescription: Examines women's place in political theory and the practice of politics in the United States. A major focus is to trace the development of women's political rights, the impact of public policy on the lives of American women and to see how women influence and participate in the political process.

This seminar focuses on the politics of the American South from the 1940s to the present.  Emphasis is on introducing students to contrasting explanations and analysis about the politics of the American South.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Debate and discussion of contrasting views

courseDescription: Surveys major areas of public international law (e.g., laws of warfare, law of the sea, conflict resolution, etc.).  Emphasizes the relationship between international law and international politics.
Technical and Digital Skills: Familiarity with law of the sea
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of international politics and law

courseDescription: Course provides a basis for understanding the role and importance of international organizations in contemporary international relations.  Focuses on development and history of global organizations, with particular emphasis on the United Nations, and regional and functional organizations.
Technical and Digital Skills: Familiarity with regional and functional organizations
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Understanding of historical and contemporary issues in global organizations

courseTitle: Political Participation in the United States
courseDescription: An examination of current theories and research on political behavior, conventional and unconventional modes of political participation, and the impact of participation on the political system.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding impact of political participation on the political system
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading discussions on political theories and participation

Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluation of political and economic reforms

Technical and Digital Skills: Research on East Asia contemporary issues

The formulation and conduct of U.S. foreign policy under changing domestic and external circumstances.  Models of decision making; interrelationships of economic, political, and military factors; major trends in contemporary American foreign policy making.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership in diverse domestic and external situations

courseDescription: Comparative study of foreign policy behavior.  Internal and external factors in formation and implementation of foreign policy.  Examination and application of foreign policy models.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Understanding and interpreting internal and external factors influencing foreign policy
Critical evaluation of foreign policy models

courseDescription: Examines U.S. national security policy, strategy and the use of force, the formulation and execution of policy, the international dimension of national security, and contemporary issues in national security.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Interpretation and communication of policy implications
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of international security issues

courseDescription: Independent research in political science under the supervision of a faculty member.
